The House of Representatives: version of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act would tax graduate tuition waivers, while the Senate version keeps the exemption from taxation.
The final version of the tax bill: if passed, may or may not include an end to the exemption of tuition waivers from taxation.
Currently: U.S. law states that individuals do not have to count tuition write-offs as taxable income, including graduate students who teach and perform research in return for free tuition.
Section 117: d) of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code provides a definition of "qualified tuition reduction" that includes both undergraduate and graduate tuition write-offs in the exemption.
